question_text: How does the weak O–O bond dissociation energy in hydroperoxides influence their role in low-temperature hydrocarbon oxidation and autoignition?
standard_answer: The O–O bond in hydroperoxides has a significantly lower bond dissociation energy (BDE) of approximately 211 kJ/mol for hydrogen peroxide, compared to C–C (250–440 kJ/mol), C–H (350–590 kJ/mol), and C–O/O–H bonds (330–480 kJ/mol). This low BDE facilitates facile bond dissociation, generating reactive radical species that enhance chain branching in low-temperature oxidation. In alkane oxidation, hydroperoxides like ketohydroperoxides (KHPs) decompose via O–O bond cleavage, producing OH radicals and alkoxy radicals. This decomposition accelerates reactivity, triggering first-stage autoignition (cool flame) and second-stage ignition in internal combustion engines. The weak O–O bond enables hydroperoxides to act as key branching agents, promoting radical proliferation and reducing ignition delay times through cycles involving QOOH and OOQOOH radicals, ultimately governing the negative temperature coefficient (NTC) behavior and autoignition phenomena.

original_text.1: The O–O single bond in hydroperoxides is substantially weaker than other single bonds of organic compounds. C–C bond dissociation energies (BDE) in organic compounds are most often between 250 and 440 kJ/mol and the BDEs for C–H bonds are between 350 and 590 kJ/mol. For C–O and O–H bonds, BDEs are in the range of 330–480 kJ/mol and 350–480 kJ/mol, respectively. In comparison, the BDE of the O–OH bond in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, the most stable hydroperoxide), is 211 kJ/mol.
original_text.2: These small BDEs of hydroperoxides enable bond dissociation and the formation of two radical species, leading to enhanced reactivity. As shown in Fig. 1, this easy bond dissociation has made hydroperoxides – especially ketohydroperoxides – the center of chemistry governing low-temperature oxidation and triggering autoignition in internal combustion engines.
